the-case-for-un-resolutions-why-quitting.title: The Case for "Un-Resolutions": Why Quitting is Better Than Starting
the-case-for-un-resolutions-why-quitting.content:
Every December, the pressure mounts to draft a grand plan for the new year. We are told to add new habits, start new projects, and become better versions of ourselves by January 1st. But there's a fundamental flaw in this approach: most of our lives are already loaded to maximum capacity. Adding more to an overflowing plate doesn't lead to self-improvement; it usually just leads to overwhelm.

Before you commit to a list of ambitious new goals for 2026, consider a different approach. Instead of focusing on what you need to start doing, figure out what you need to stop. Call them "un-resolutions."

The logic is simple, you can't build something new on a cluttered foundation. By identifying and removing the habits, obligations, and mindsets that drain your energy, you automatically create the space needed for actual growth. It‚Äôs subtraction for the sake of addition.

Here is how to identify what to quit, and why it‚Äôs often more effective than resolving to start something new.

The Trap of Performative Busyness

One of the most pervasive energy drains is the need to appear constantly busy. It‚Äôs the habit of saying "yes" to meetings where your input isn't needed, replying to emails within seconds just to show you're online, or filling every gap in your calendar to avoid looking unproductive.

This isn't actual work; it's performance art. And it is exhausting.

An excellent un-resolution is to stop confusing activity with productivity. Practically, this means auditing your calendar for the last month. Circle every commitment that didn't move a real project forward or provide genuine value. Your goal for next year isn't to do more, but to ruthlessly eliminate those circled items.

When you stop performing busyness, you get time back. You can spend that time doing deep, focused work, or you can simply spend it resting. Both are better alternatives.

The Default "Yes"

Many of us operate with a default "yes" to requests on our time, whether professional or personal. We agree to things in the moment to be helpful or to avoid awkwardness, only to regret it later when the deadline looms. A powerful un-resolution is to quit the immediate "yes." Replace it with a default "let me check and get back to you."

This small buffer buys you the clarity to evaluate if you actually have the bandwidth and desire to commit. It transforms your "yes" from a knee-jerk reaction into an intentional choice. You will disappoint a few people initially, but you will gain respect for managing your own capacity. More importantly, you won't burn out trying to fulfil promises you never should have made.

The Digital Pacifier

We all know we spend too much time on our phones. But framing it as "I need to spend less time scrolling" is too vague to be useful. It's like saying "I need to eat better."

Instead, identify the specific digital habit that serves as your pacifier, the thing you do blindly to soothe boredom or anxiety. Is it checking headlines the second you wake up? Is it opening a specific app every time you wait in line?

Pick one concrete digital loop and break it. For example, decide that your phone will not enter your bedroom. Buy an analog alarm clock. That single act of subtraction removes hundreds of mindless morning scrolls over the course of a year. You don't need to replace it with meditation or journaling right away. Just reclaim that mental space first.

Making Space for What Matters

Quitting habits is notoriously harder than starting them. It requires you to confront discomfort rather than distract yourself with novelty. But the payoff is substantial.

When you clear out the dead weight of old obligations and mindless routines, you don't just get time back; you get your attention back. You enter the new year not with a heavy list of new burdens, but with a lighter load. And sometimes, travelling lighter is the best way to get where you want to go.
the-case-for-un-resolutions-why-quitting.excerpt: Every December, the pressure mounts to add new goals to our already overflowing plates. But real progress requires space, not clutter. Before you commit to more, discover why the smartest move for 2026 is defining your "un-resolutions", and learning what to quit.

fate-or-coincidence.title: FATE OR COINCIDENCE?
fate-or-coincidence.content:
It‚Äôs painful when you see people work so hard, come so close, and then things don‚Äôt go their way at the last minute. For some, it begs the question why try in the first place?

I‚Äôve seen situations that make it easy to understand how people can give up and develop low self-esteem.

What‚Äôs even crazier is realizing that the universe doesn‚Äôt always reward good people. Sometimes, it really just sucks.

You can be kind, helpful, and do your part for society, and still have bad things happen to you. There‚Äôs no manual for this thing called life.

That‚Äôs why I always say, ‚ÄúAt the end of it all, your conscience will be your biggest judge.‚Äù

Trying to decode how life works might not get you anywhere. Why do things happen? Is it fate? Coincidence? Who really knows?

Just do your best, Live your life, Enjoy the moments. And at the top of it all, hope that nature doesn‚Äôt betray you.
